cot.content:
To solve the problem, Please think and reason step by step, then answer.
question:
who is the owner of the crowne plaza
        
Generation Format:
Reasoning process:
Answer:

Reasoning process:
1. The Crowne Plaza brand is part of the InterContinental Hotels Group (IHG), which is a multinational hotel company.
2. IHG operates various hotel brands, including Crowne Plaza, Holiday Inn, and InterContinental.
3. To determine the owner of Crowne Plaza, we need to identify the parent company that manages the brand.
4. Since Crowne Plaza is not independently owned but is a brand under IHG, the owner of Crowne Plaza is IHG.

Answer:
The owner of Crowne Plaza is InterContinental Hotels Group (IHG).

anchoring.content:
You are a cognitive scientist, to answer the following question:
who is the owner of the crowne plaza
I will provide you with several retrieved passages:
Passages:
['In September 2017, Massachusetts Mutual Life sold the hotel building to a new owner, EOS DCH Owner LLC, for $106.5 million. The hotel disassociated from the Crowne Plaza brand, and became an independent property.\n', "In June 2005, Santander Real's investment fund acquired 50% of the building for €138.6 million, committing to purchase the remaining 50% belonging to the hotel shortly thereafter. The Crowne Plaza Hotel occupying the building closed in 2006. The deal closed in early December 2007. Santander renovated the building, preserving intact the facade and the lobby as part of a project to build a hotel and apartments, but the project stalled in 2010.\n", 'It was sold again in mid-2010 for $47.8m to local company Hargate Properties who retained the affiliation with Crowne Plaza Hotels but the new owners went into receivership in November 2011. The purchase of the hotel by Kevyn Frederick in 2010 later was discovered to be part of a large mortgage fraud in the Edmonton area.\n', 'As investment executive of Optima Ventures, Schochet has presided over the acquisition of a number of properties in Cleveland, Ohio including One Cleveland Center (purchased for $86.3 million in 2008); 55 Public Square (purchased for $34 million); the Huntington Bank Building (purchased for $18.5 million in 2010); and the Penton Media Building. In October 2011, Optima entered its first joint venture, buying the 472-room Crowne Plaza Cleveland City Centre hotel with Sage Hospitality Resources, a hotel developer and manager based in Colorado. In September 2014, Schochet and Chip Marous proposed a $231 million renovation of the Huntington Bank Building, the second largest office building in the city, into a mixed-used facility combining offices, apartments, condominiums and a boutique hotel. In June 2015, Terry Coyne, a commercial real estate broker with Newmark, negotiated and coordinated the sale of the building to Andrew “Avi” Greenbaum, principal of Hudson Holdings, for $22.5 million. Hudson began a $280 million renovation of the building which will feature 550 apartments, a 300-room, high-end hotel, feet of retail, a banquet hall, conference space, and a lobby open to the public.\n', 'In February 2017, Barry Felstead replaced Rowen Craigie as CEO Crown Resorts Melbourne.\n', 'In 2004, the building was sold by the Slovak republic to the Dutch company "Myria Assets" for 425 million Slovak crowns. Today, the hotel is called "Crowne Plaza".\n', 'Encana officially confirmed on June 16, 2008, that Jaume Plensa, an artist most famous for the Crown Fountain in Chicago, had been chosen to complete two major public art installations for the project. The first work, entitled "Wonderland", was unveiled on January 25, 2013, on the south plaza. The second work, entitled "Alberta\'s Dream" is located on the north side and depicts a bronze casting of the artist embracing a living tree.\n', "The Crowne Plaza in Christchurch, New Zealand, originally known as the Parkroyal Hotel, was a hotel of the Crowne Plaza group. Built in 1988 in the north-west corner of Victoria Square after much public protest, as it cut off the first part of Victoria Street, its construction happened at the same time and enabled the substantial redesign of Victoria Square. The building had New Zealand's largest atrium, and was one of the city's largest hotels. The building suffered significant damage in the 2011 Christchurch earthquake and was demolished in April 2012. The Crowne Plaza group has secured a lease in the Forsyth Barr Building at the opposite end of Victoria Square.\n", 'In March 2012, the hotel was sold by the Receiver, David Findling to an unnamed investor who reportedly planned to renovate it and enter into a management agreement with Crowne Plaza Hotels & Resorts, a division of InterContinental Hotels . The Detroit Metro Convention & Visitors Bureau reported that the purchaser was Mexico-based developer Gabriel Ruiz.\n', 'Crowne Plaza Hong Kong Causeway Bay is owned by the SEA Group. The SEA Group was founded in 1956 and was listed on the Hong Kong Stock Exchange in 1973 (SEHK: 0251). The Group has been active in both property investments and developments and have to-date developed or owned over 200 properties development in Hong Kong, Mainland China, Australia, Canada, Indonesia, Japan, New Zealand and United Kingdom – with businesses covering hotel, residential, commercial, industrial sectors and etc. Other hotel projects include the Lizard Island Resort on the Great Barrier Reef, Australia.\n']

Task Description:
Please extract content that may be unfamiliar to the model from these passages, 
which can provide the model with relevant background and unknown knowledge and concepts, 
helping it better understand the question. and analyze the role of these contents.

To answer the question about the ownership of Crowne Plaza, we can extract and analyze relevant information from the provided passages. Here are some key points and their implications:

1. **Ownership Changes**:
   - The passages indicate that ownership of properties associated with the Crowne Plaza brand has changed multiple times. For instance, one passage mentions that in September 2017, Massachusetts Mutual Life sold a hotel building to EOS DCH Owner LLC, which then disassociated from the Crowne Plaza brand. This suggests that ownership can significantly impact branding and management decisions.

2. **Investment and Development**:
   - The passage about Optima Ventures and their joint venture with Sage Hospitality Resources highlights the involvement of investment firms in acquiring and renovating Crowne Plaza properties. This indicates that Crowne Plaza hotels may often be part of larger investment strategies, which can influence their operational and financial performance.

3. **Geographical Diversity**:
   - The mention of Crowne Plaza hotels in various locations, such as Christchurch, New Zealand, and Hong Kong, illustrates the brand's global presence. This geographical diversity can affect ownership structures, as different regions may have different investors and market conditions.

4. **Management Agreements**:
   - The passage discussing the sale of a hotel to an unnamed investor who planned to enter into a management agreement with Crowne Plaza Hotels & Resorts indicates that ownership does not always equate to direct management. Instead, many hotels operate under management agreements with larger hotel chains, which can complicate the understanding of "ownership."

5. **Corporate Structure**:
   - The reference to Crowne Plaza Hotels & Resorts being a division of InterContinental Hotels suggests that the brand is part of a larger corporate structure. Understanding this hierarchy is crucial for comprehending how ownership and management decisions are made at the brand level.

6. **Local Ownership**:
   - The mention of local companies, such as Hargate Properties and the unnamed investor in Detroit, indicates that local ownership can play a significant role in the management and operation of Crowne Plaza hotels. This local involvement can lead to different operational strategies compared to those managed by larger, international firms.

### Role of Extracted Content:
The extracted content provides a broader context for understanding the complexities of hotel ownership, particularly for a brand like Crowne Plaza. It highlights the dynamic nature of ownership, the influence of investment strategies, the importance of management agreements, and the impact of local versus corporate ownership. This context is essential for answering questions about ownership accurately, as it emphasizes that ownership can be multifaceted and subject to change based on various factors, including market conditions and corporate strategies. 

In summary, the ownership of Crowne Plaza hotels is not static and can involve various stakeholders, including local investors, larger corporate entities, and management agreements that influence how the brand operates in different regions.

knowledge enhanced inference process:
Answer:

### Knowledge Enhanced Inference Process:

1. **Understanding Brand Ownership**:
   - The Crowne Plaza brand is part of the InterContinental Hotels Group (IHG), a multinational hotel company that manages several hotel brands, including Crowne Plaza, Holiday Inn, and InterContinental. This establishes that the brand itself is not independently owned but is under the umbrella of a larger corporate entity.

2. **Dynamic Ownership of Properties**:
   - Ownership of individual Crowne Plaza properties can change frequently. For example, the passages indicate that properties associated with the Crowne Plaza brand have been sold to various owners, such as EOS DCH Owner LLC and local companies like Hargate Properties. This suggests that while IHG owns the brand, the actual physical hotels may have different owners.

3. **Investment Strategies**:
   - The involvement of investment firms, such as Optima Ventures, in acquiring and renovating Crowne Plaza properties indicates that these hotels are often part of larger investment strategies. This can influence how properties are managed and operated, and it highlights the role of financial entities in the hospitality industry.

4. **Geographical Diversity and Local Ownership**:
   - Crowne Plaza hotels are located in various regions, which can lead to different ownership structures. Local investors may own specific properties, while IHG manages the brand. This geographical diversity can affect operational strategies and market positioning.

5. **Management Agreements**:
   - Many Crowne Plaza hotels operate under management agreements with IHG, meaning that while IHG manages the brand and provides operational support, the actual ownership may reside with different investors. This distinction is crucial for understanding the complexities of hotel ownership.

6. **Corporate Structure**:
   - Recognizing that Crowne Plaza Hotels & Resorts is a division of IHG helps clarify the corporate hierarchy. This structure is essential for understanding how decisions are made regarding branding, management, and operations.

### Conclusion:
The ownership of Crowne Plaza is multifaceted, involving both the overarching brand ownership by IHG and the individual ownership of specific hotel properties by various investors. This complexity is important for accurately answering questions about ownership.

### Answer:
The owner of the Crowne Plaza brand is InterContinental Hotels Group (IHG). However, individual Crowne Plaza hotels may be owned by various local or investment entities, while IHG manages the brand and its operations.

By participating in this collaborative discussion, you will deepen the model's understanding through the synthesis of multiple expert perspectives.

**Expert Discussion on Ownership of Crowne Plaza**

**Expert 1: Historical Context Specialist**
The ownership of Crowne Plaza hotels has varied significantly over the years, as evidenced by the passages. For instance, the hotel in Christchurch, originally known as the Parkroyal, was a part of the Crowne Plaza group but was demolished after the 2011 earthquake. This highlights how external factors, such as natural disasters, can impact hotel ownership and branding. Furthermore, the sale of properties like the one in Massachusetts to EOS DCH Owner LLC illustrates that hotels can disassociate from the Crowne Plaza brand, leading to independent ownership.

**Expert 2: Real Estate and Investment Analyst**
From a financial perspective, the transactions involving Crowne Plaza properties reveal a complex landscape of ownership. The sale of the hotel building in Massachusetts for $106.5 million and the subsequent disassociation from the brand indicates a strategic move by the new owners. Additionally, the involvement of investment funds like Santander Real and local companies such as Hargate Properties shows that ownership can be fragmented and influenced by market conditions. The mention of mortgage fraud in the Edmonton area also raises concerns about the integrity of ownership transactions in the hospitality sector.

**Expert 3: Brand Management and Hospitality Expert**
The Crowne Plaza brand itself is managed by InterContinental Hotels Group (IHG), which plays a crucial role in the branding and operational standards of its hotels. The passage discussing the unnamed investor planning to enter into a management agreement with Crowne Plaza Hotels & Resorts emphasizes the importance of brand affiliation for operational success. This suggests that while ownership may change, the brand's value and management practices remain integral to the hotel's identity.

**Expert 4: Regional Development and Urban Planning Specialist**
The ownership of Crowne Plaza hotels is also influenced by regional development trends. For example, the SEA Group's ownership of Crowne Plaza Hong Kong Causeway Bay reflects the group's broader strategy in property investments across various sectors. This indicates that ownership can be part of larger urban development initiatives, where hotels serve as key components in revitalizing areas or enhancing tourism.

**Points of Agreement:**
- All experts agree that ownership of Crowne Plaza hotels is dynamic and can change due to various factors, including market conditions, natural disasters, and strategic business decisions.
- The importance of brand management and affiliation with IHG is recognized as a critical aspect of maintaining the hotel's identity and operational standards.

**Points of Disagreement:**
- There is a divergence in emphasis on the implications of ownership changes. While the Historical Context Specialist focuses on the impact of external factors, the Real Estate Analyst emphasizes financial transactions and market integrity.
- The Regional Development Specialist highlights the role of ownership in urban planning, which may not be as pronounced in the discussions of the other experts.

**Synthesis of Insights:**
The discussion reveals that the ownership of Crowne Plaza hotels is multifaceted, influenced by historical events, financial transactions, brand management, and regional development. Each perspective contributes to a deeper understanding of how ownership is not merely a matter of property title but is intertwined with broader economic, social, and environmental contexts. The dynamic nature of hotel ownership underscores the importance of adaptability in the hospitality industry, where brand affiliation and strategic management play pivotal roles in sustaining operational success.

In conclusion, the ownership of Crowne Plaza hotels is a complex interplay of various factors, and understanding this complexity enhances our comprehension of the hospitality sector's challenges and opportunities.

To enhance the model's causal reasoning and logical inference abilities, we can extract and consolidate relevant information from the provided passages regarding ownership transitions of Crowne Plaza hotels. Here’s a summary of the key points:

1. **Ownership Changes**:
   - In September 2017, Massachusetts Mutual Life sold a hotel building to EOS DCH Owner LLC, which then disassociated from the Crowne Plaza brand.
   - In June 2005, Santander Real's investment fund acquired 50% of a building that housed a Crowne Plaza hotel, but the hotel closed in 2006.
   - The hotel was sold again in mid-2010 to Hargate Properties, which retained the Crowne Plaza affiliation, but later went into receivership.
   - In October 2011, Optima Ventures acquired the Crowne Plaza Cleveland City Centre hotel in a joint venture with Sage Hospitality Resources.
   - In March 2012, a hotel was sold to an unnamed investor who planned to renovate it and enter into a management agreement with Crowne Plaza Hotels & Resorts, with reports suggesting the purchaser was Gabriel Ruiz.
   - Crowne Plaza Hong Kong Causeway Bay is owned by the SEA Group, which has a diverse portfolio in property investments and developments.

2. **Brand Affiliation**:
   - Several passages indicate that ownership does not always equate to brand affiliation. For instance, after being sold, some properties disassociated from the Crowne Plaza brand, while others retained it despite changes in ownership.

3. **Market Dynamics**:
   - The passages illustrate the complexities of hotel ownership, including financial challenges (e.g., receivership, mortgage fraud) and strategic decisions (e.g., renovations, brand management agreements).

### Analysis of Impact on Causal Reasoning and Logical Inference

1. **Understanding Ownership Dynamics**:
   - By analyzing the transitions of ownership and brand affiliation, the model can learn to infer that ownership changes can lead to brand changes, but not always. This understanding is crucial for making predictions about future ownership and branding strategies in the hospitality industry.

2. **Identifying Causal Relationships**:
   - The model can develop the ability to recognize causal relationships, such as how financial difficulties (e.g., receivership) can lead to changes in ownership or brand affiliation. This can enhance the model's ability to predict outcomes based on initial conditions.

3. **Complexity of Business Transactions**:
   - The information highlights the complexity of business transactions in the hotel industry, where multiple stakeholders (investors, developers, management companies) are involved. The model can learn to navigate these complexities and make inferences about potential future transactions based on historical data.

4. **Impact of External Factors**:
   - The passages suggest that external factors (e.g., market conditions, economic downturns) can influence ownership and management decisions. The model can improve its reasoning by incorporating these external variables into its analyses.

In summary, the extracted content provides a rich context for understanding the dynamics of hotel ownership and brand management. By analyzing these relationships, the model can enhance its causal reasoning and logical inference capabilities, allowing it to make more informed predictions and analyses in similar contexts.

who is the owner of the crowne plaza
answer:
Reasoning process:
1. The Crowne Plaza brand is part of the InterContinental Hotels Group (IHG), which is a multinational hotel company.
2. IHG operates various hotel brands, including Crowne Plaza, Holiday Inn, and InterContinental.
3. To determine the owner of Crowne Plaza, we need to identify the parent company that manages the brand.
4. Since Crowne Plaza is not independently owned but is a brand under IHG, the owner of Crowne Plaza is IHG.

Answer:
The owner of Crowne Plaza is InterContinental Hotels Group (IHG).

cognition.content:
Fact-checking refers to the process of confirming the accuracy of a statement or claim through various sources or methods. 
This process aims to ensure that statements or claims are based on reliable and verifiable information while eliminating inaccurate or misleading content. 
Fact-checking may involve the examination of data, literature, expert opinions, or other trustworthy sources.
In the context of artificial intelligence, model illusion refers to the overconfidence response of the AI. 
When a model exhibits an 'illusion' (a tendency to output deceptive data), it indicates that the training data used by the model does not necessarily support the rationality of its outputs.
You are a scientist researching fact-checking and addressing model illusions in artificial intelligence. 
To answer the following question:
who is the owner of the crowne plaza
I will provide you with several retrieved passages:
Passages:
['In September 2017, Massachusetts Mutual Life sold the hotel building to a new owner, EOS DCH Owner LLC, for $106.5 million. The hotel disassociated from the Crowne Plaza brand, and became an independent property.\n', "In June 2005, Santander Real's investment fund acquired 50% of the building for €138.6 million, committing to purchase the remaining 50% belonging to the hotel shortly thereafter. The Crowne Plaza Hotel occupying the building closed in 2006. The deal closed in early December 2007. Santander renovated the building, preserving intact the facade and the lobby as part of a project to build a hotel and apartments, but the project stalled in 2010.\n", 'It was sold again in mid-2010 for $47.8m to local company Hargate Properties who retained the affiliation with Crowne Plaza Hotels but the new owners went into receivership in November 2011. The purchase of the hotel by Kevyn Frederick in 2010 later was discovered to be part of a large mortgage fraud in the Edmonton area.\n', 'As investment executive of Optima Ventures, Schochet has presided over the acquisition of a number of properties in Cleveland, Ohio including One Cleveland Center (purchased for $86.3 million in 2008); 55 Public Square (purchased for $34 million); the Huntington Bank Building (purchased for $18.5 million in 2010); and the Penton Media Building. In October 2011, Optima entered its first joint venture, buying the 472-room Crowne Plaza Cleveland City Centre hotel with Sage Hospitality Resources, a hotel developer and manager based in Colorado. In September 2014, Schochet and Chip Marous proposed a $231 million renovation of the Huntington Bank Building, the second largest office building in the city, into a mixed-used facility combining offices, apartments, condominiums and a boutique hotel. In June 2015, Terry Coyne, a commercial real estate broker with Newmark, negotiated and coordinated the sale of the building to Andrew “Avi” Greenbaum, principal of Hudson Holdings, for $22.5 million. Hudson began a $280 million renovation of the building which will feature 550 apartments, a 300-room, high-end hotel, feet of retail, a banquet hall, conference space, and a lobby open to the public.\n', 'In February 2017, Barry Felstead replaced Rowen Craigie as CEO Crown Resorts Melbourne.\n', 'In 2004, the building was sold by the Slovak republic to the Dutch company "Myria Assets" for 425 million Slovak crowns. Today, the hotel is called "Crowne Plaza".\n', 'Encana officially confirmed on June 16, 2008, that Jaume Plensa, an artist most famous for the Crown Fountain in Chicago, had been chosen to complete two major public art installations for the project. The first work, entitled "Wonderland", was unveiled on January 25, 2013, on the south plaza. The second work, entitled "Alberta\'s Dream" is located on the north side and depicts a bronze casting of the artist embracing a living tree.\n', "The Crowne Plaza in Christchurch, New Zealand, originally known as the Parkroyal Hotel, was a hotel of the Crowne Plaza group. Built in 1988 in the north-west corner of Victoria Square after much public protest, as it cut off the first part of Victoria Street, its construction happened at the same time and enabled the substantial redesign of Victoria Square. The building had New Zealand's largest atrium, and was one of the city's largest hotels. The building suffered significant damage in the 2011 Christchurch earthquake and was demolished in April 2012. The Crowne Plaza group has secured a lease in the Forsyth Barr Building at the opposite end of Victoria Square.\n", 'In March 2012, the hotel was sold by the Receiver, David Findling to an unnamed investor who reportedly planned to renovate it and enter into a management agreement with Crowne Plaza Hotels & Resorts, a division of InterContinental Hotels . The Detroit Metro Convention & Visitors Bureau reported that the purchaser was Mexico-based developer Gabriel Ruiz.\n', 'Crowne Plaza Hong Kong Causeway Bay is owned by the SEA Group. The SEA Group was founded in 1956 and was listed on the Hong Kong Stock Exchange in 1973 (SEHK: 0251). The Group has been active in both property investments and developments and have to-date developed or owned over 200 properties development in Hong Kong, Mainland China, Australia, Canada, Indonesia, Japan, New Zealand and United Kingdom – with businesses covering hotel, residential, commercial, industrial sectors and etc. Other hotel projects include the Lizard Island Resort on the Great Barrier Reef, Australia.\n']

**Knowledge Enhanced Inference Process:**

1. The Crowne Plaza brand is indeed part of the InterContinental Hotels Group (IHG), which is a multinational hotel company that manages various hotel brands, including Crowne Plaza, Holiday Inn, and InterContinental.

2. However, it is important to note that not all Crowne Plaza hotels are owned by IHG. Ownership can vary significantly from one location to another. For instance, the Crowne Plaza Hong Kong Causeway Bay is owned by the SEA Group, indicating that individual properties may have different owners while still operating under the Crowne Plaza brand.

3. Additionally, there are instances where hotels operate under the Crowne Plaza brand through management agreements rather than direct ownership. For example, a hotel sold in March 2012 was planned to enter into a management agreement with Crowne Plaza Hotels & Resorts, which means that while IHG manages the brand, the actual ownership can belong to different investors or companies.

4. The ownership landscape can change over time, as evidenced by the passage mentioning that in September 2017, a hotel previously associated with Crowne Plaza disassociated from the brand and became an independent property after being sold. This highlights the dynamic nature of hotel ownership and brand affiliation.

5. Historical context is also relevant, as some properties may have undergone significant changes, such as the Crowne Plaza in Christchurch, which was originally known as the Parkroyal Hotel and was demolished after the 2011 earthquake. Understanding these changes can provide insight into the brand's evolution and the status of specific properties.

By incorporating this nuanced understanding of ownership, management agreements, and historical context, the model can provide a more accurate and comprehensive response regarding the ownership of Crowne Plaza hotels.

**Answer:**
The owner of the Crowne Plaza brand is InterContinental Hotels Group (IHG), which manages the brand. However, individual Crowne Plaza hotels may be owned by different entities. For example, the Crowne Plaza Hong Kong Causeway Bay is owned by the SEA Group, and some properties operate under management agreements with IHG rather than being directly owned by it. Additionally, ownership can change over time, as seen in instances where hotels have disassociated from the Crowne Plaza brand.

question_info.question: who is the owner of the crowne plaza
passages:
In September 2017, Massachusetts Mutual Life sold the hotel building to a new owner, EOS DCH Owner LLC, for $106.5 million. The hotel disassociated from the Crowne Plaza brand, and became an independent property.
In June 2005, Santander Real's investment fund acquired 50% of the building for €138.6 million, committing to purchase the remaining 50% belonging to the hotel shortly thereafter. The Crowne Plaza Hotel occupying the building closed in 2006. The deal closed in early December 2007. Santander renovated the building, preserving intact the facade and the lobby as part of a project to build a hotel and apartments, but the project stalled in 2010.
It was sold again in mid-2010 for $47.8m to local company Hargate Properties who retained the affiliation with Crowne Plaza Hotels but the new owners went into receivership in November 2011. The purchase of the hotel by Kevyn Frederick in 2010 later was discovered to be part of a large mortgage fraud in the Edmonton area.
As investment executive of Optima Ventures, Schochet has presided over the acquisition of a number of properties in Cleveland, Ohio including One Cleveland Center (purchased for $86.3 million in 2008); 55 Public Square (purchased for $34 million); the Huntington Bank Building (purchased for $18.5 million in 2010); and the Penton Media Building. In October 2011, Optima entered its first joint venture, buying the 472-room Crowne Plaza Cleveland City Centre hotel with Sage Hospitality Resources, a hotel developer and manager based in Colorado. In September 2014, Schochet and Chip Marous proposed a $231 million renovation of the Huntington Bank Building, the second largest office building in the city, into a mixed-used facility combining offices, apartments, condominiums and a boutique hotel. In June 2015, Terry Coyne, a commercial real estate broker with Newmark, negotiated and coordinated the sale of the building to Andrew “Avi” Greenbaum, principal of Hudson Holdings, for $22.5 million. Hudson began a $280 million renovation of the building which will feature 550 apartments, a 300-room, high-end hotel, feet of retail, a banquet hall, conference space, and a lobby open to the public.
In February 2017, Barry Felstead replaced Rowen Craigie as CEO Crown Resorts Melbourne.
In 2004, the building was sold by the Slovak republic to the Dutch company "Myria Assets" for 425 million Slovak crowns. Today, the hotel is called "Crowne Plaza".
Encana officially confirmed on June 16, 2008, that Jaume Plensa, an artist most famous for the Crown Fountain in Chicago, had been chosen to complete two major public art installations for the project. The first work, entitled "Wonderland", was unveiled on January 25, 2013, on the south plaza. The second work, entitled "Alberta's Dream" is located on the north side and depicts a bronze casting of the artist embracing a living tree.
The Crowne Plaza in Christchurch, New Zealand, originally known as the Parkroyal Hotel, was a hotel of the Crowne Plaza group. Built in 1988 in the north-west corner of Victoria Square after much public protest, as it cut off the first part of Victoria Street, its construction happened at the same time and enabled the substantial redesign of Victoria Square. The building had New Zealand's largest atrium, and was one of the city's largest hotels. The building suffered significant damage in the 2011 Christchurch earthquake and was demolished in April 2012. The Crowne Plaza group has secured a lease in the Forsyth Barr Building at the opposite end of Victoria Square.
In March 2012, the hotel was sold by the Receiver, David Findling to an unnamed investor who reportedly planned to renovate it and enter into a management agreement with Crowne Plaza Hotels & Resorts, a division of InterContinental Hotels . The Detroit Metro Convention & Visitors Bureau reported that the purchaser was Mexico-based developer Gabriel Ruiz.
Crowne Plaza Hong Kong Causeway Bay is owned by the SEA Group. The SEA Group was founded in 1956 and was listed on the Hong Kong Stock Exchange in 1973 (SEHK: 0251). The Group has been active in both property investments and developments and have to-date developed or owned over 200 properties development in Hong Kong, Mainland China, Australia, Canada, Indonesia, Japan, New Zealand and United Kingdom – with businesses covering hotel, residential, commercial, industrial sectors and etc. Other hotel projects include the Lizard Island Resort on the Great Barrier Reef, Australia.
